html.p: There are two options you can follow here to create your Big Assumptions.

Option 1) Use deduction. Look at one of your Hidden Commitments. Now ask yourself, "what assumptions must I be making that make this commitment necessary for me?" "What could be the assumptions I hold that sustain this commitment?" For example, if I am committed to always being right, what might I be assuming? Maybe…

ul.li: I assume that if I am not right, I can't feel good about myself.
I assume that if I am not right, others won't trust me.
I assume that if I am not right, no one will like me.
I assume I am either right or wrong.
I assume I should never say or do something that might turn out to be wrong.
I assume that if I am always right, I will always feel good about myself.
Only you know which Big Assumption is true for you.

html.p: Sometimes worry box entries (rather than Hidden Commitments) reveal assumptions.

blockquote.p: Here is Fred's worry box entry: "If I were to schedule writing time, I'm afraid I would feel like my creativity is being stifled." This assumption underlies that fear: If I were to schedule writing time, I assume that I would feel like my creativity is being stifled. That is an assumption Fred is making. Fred may feel that assumption is 100% true. Or he may know it is not 100% true, but also admit that he acts as if it is. Or he may be unsure about whether it is true or not.

Option 2) Use the formula. Choose a 3rd column commitment and consider its inverse (e.g. "I am committed to never revealing that I don't have all the answers." The inverse is "I do reveal I don't have all the answers.") Now construct a sentence, the first half of which is in this form: I assume that if [inverse of 3rd column entry] THEN: the second half of the sentence will be your honest completion of the sentence. e.g. I assume that if I do reveal I don't have all the answers… then I will be considered a fraud.

Let's work with Fred's Hidden Commitment: "I am committed to never feeling stifled or under force." The inverse if "I do feel stifled or forced." His formula is: "I assume that if I do feel stifled or forced, then I will feel absolutely awful, my creative spark will be extinguished, and it might be permanent."

html.p: Please review your map so far, especially your Hidden Commitments, before entering your Big Assumptions.
